title: R45525
content: Congress has been actively shaping federal agricultural policy since the 1930s through periodic farm legislation. The scope of policy areas covered in farm bills has expanded to include conservation, credit, rural development, nutrition assistance, trade, organic agriculture, forestry, and support for farmers and ranchers. The Agriculture Improvement Act of 2018, known as the "2018 farm bill," was enacted on December 20, 2018. The Agriculture Improvement Act of 2018, known as the "2018 farm bill," was enacted on December 20, 2018, after passing through various stages in the House and Senate. The 2018 farm bill, known as the Agriculture Improvement Act, establishes policy for agriculture and nutrition programs across 12 titles. The bill projects $428 billion in spending over five years, with 76% allocated to the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) and the remaining 24% for agricultural programs like crop insurance and conservation. The 2018 farm bill, also known as the Agriculture Improvement Act, covers agricultural programs such as crop insurance, farm commodity programs, and conservation. The bill is estimated to be budget neutral over a 10-year period, with an initial increase in spending of $1.8 billion in the first five years offset by savings in the following five years. The policymaking environment for this bill differed from the 2014 farm bill due to lower farm income levels and disruptions in agricultural exports. The decline in net cash farm income is attributed to lower farm prices for commodities and disruptions in farm exports due to trade disputes. This has led to tariffs being imposed on U.S. farm product exports by major trading partners. The enacted farm bill provides farmers and ranchers with continuity for the next five years amidst uncertainty about agricultural exports. The report analyzes the budget implications of the enacted 2018 farm bill compared to prior laws. It includes summaries of changes in the bill and tables with a title-by-title analysis. CBO estimates are used to measure federal spending and the impact on policy. The farm bill authorizes funding for mandatory outlays and sets parameters for discretionary programs. The 2018 farm bill sets parameters for discretionary programs and authorizes future appropriations but does not provide funding. Mandatory programs dominate the farm bill policy and budget debate, with a total of $428 billion projected over five years. The nutrition title is the largest component of the budget, followed by crop insurance, farm commodity programs, and conservation. Mandatory spending proposals are measured against the CBO baseline, which projects future federal spending on mandatory programs under current law. The CBO baseline used to develop the 2018 farm bill projected that farm bill programs would cost $867 billion over the next 10 years, with 77% allocated to the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) and 23% for agricultural programs. The 2018 farm bill primarily focused on agricultural programs such as crop insurance, farm commodity programs, and conservation. Changes in spending relative to the baseline were scored, with positive scores indicating an increase in spending and negative scores indicating a decrease. The enacted 2018 farm bill's impact on spending is detailed in Table 3 and Figure 3. The 2018 farm bill, including the House and Senate bills, was budget neutral over a 10-year period. The House bill would have decreased outlays by $1.8 billion, while the Senate bill was budget neutral. The enacted farm bill closely followed the Senate bill's score, with reductions mainly in the Rural Development title. Six titles saw increased spending over 10 years, including farm Commodities, Trade, Research, Energy, Horticulture, and Miscellaneous. The Conservation and Nutrition titles in the 2018 farm bill had increases over the first five years but were budget neutral over the 10-year period. The Conservation title reallocated spending across programs more than other titles. Some programs without baseline from the 2014 farm bill received continuing funding in the 2018 farm bill, with some even receiving permanent baseline. The 2018 farm bill included new programs and provisions, with the majority of the total amount allocated to the Nutrition title for SNAP. The projected outlays for agricultural programs totaled $102 billion over five years. The 2018 farm bill allocated $102 billion for agricultural programs, including crop insurance, farm commodity programs, and conservation. Title I authorizes support programs for dairy, sugar, and covered commodities, as well as disaster assistance. Major field-crop programs include PLC, ARC, and MAL. The dairy program protects the margin between milk and feed prices, while the sugar program provides price support and limits on imports. Disaster assistance programs focus on livestock and tree crops. The 2018 farm bill extends federal disaster assistance programs for farmers recovering from natural disasters, with modifications to commodity programs like ARC, PLC, and MAL. Producers were allowed to choose between ARC and PLC under the 2014 farm bill. The 2018 farm bill allows producers to switch between ARC and PLC coverage on a commodity-by-commodity basis, with the option to sign multi-year contracts. Base acres not planted to eligible commodities from 2009-2017 are not eligible for ARC and PLC payments. The 2018 farm bill allows producers to switch between ARC and PLC coverage on a commodity-by-commodity basis, with the option to sign multi-year contracts. Base acres not planted to eligible commodities from 2009-2017 are not eligible for ARC and PLC payments. However, these base acres may be enrolled in the Conservation Stewardship Program for five years at an annual program payment rate of $18 per acre. Changes to the PLC program include updating program yields based on 90% of the average yield for 2013-2017 and an escalator provision that could potentially raise a covered commodity's effective reference price by as much as 115% of the statutory PLC reference price. The 2018 farm bill also specifies changes to the ARC program. The 2018 farm bill brings changes to the ARC program, prioritizing data from USDA's Risk Management Agency for county average yields. This aims to enhance program integrity and prevent payment disparities between neighboring counties. Additionally, up to 25 counties meeting specific criteria may subdivide for ARC calculations. The 2018 farm bill brings changes to the ARC program, allowing for subdivision of acres for ARC benchmark calculations based on county average yields. ARC will now use trend-adjusted yields and increase the yield floor to 80% of transitional county yield. Marketing assistance loan rates are increased for various program crops, excluding some commodities like upland cotton and peanuts. The 2018 farm bill brings changes to the ARC program, allowing for subdivision of acres for ARC benchmark calculations based on county average yields. Marketing assistance loan rates are increased for various program crops, excluding upland cotton, peanuts, minor oilseeds, nongraded wool, mohair, and honey. Payment limits and AGI limits remain unchanged, but eligibility criteria for commodity program payment eligibility are modified. Family farm definition is expanded to include first cousins, nieces, and nephews. The enacted bill expands the family farm definition to include first cousins, nieces, and nephews, increasing the pool of individuals eligible for payment limits. It also amends agricultural disaster assistance programs, providing payments for livestock losses and expanding eligibility to include Indian tribes. Payment limits under disaster assistance programs are adjusted, with the Livestock Forage Program exempt from the $125,000/person limit. The Noninsured Crop Disaster Assistance Program is also amended to adjust crop eligibility. The enacted bill expands the family farm definition to include more relatives and amends agricultural disaster assistance programs. It adjusts crop eligibility for the Crop Disaster Assistance Program and revises the Margin Protection Program for milk producers to create the Dairy Margin Coverage program. The Dairy Margin Coverage (DMC) program allows dairy producers to purchase margin coverage from $4.00/cwt to $9.50/cwt on the first 5 million pounds of production. Producers can now cover from 5% to 95% of their production history, compared to 25% to 90% under the previous program. Premiums for Tier I coverage above $4.00/cwt are reduced to incentivize higher levels of margin coverage. Under the Dairy Margin Coverage (DMC) program, dairy producers can purchase margin coverage from $4.00/cwt to $9.50/cwt on the first 5 million pounds of production. Premiums for higher margin levels are reduced to encourage increased coverage. Producers can receive a 25% discount on premiums by locking in coverage levels for five years. Repayment of premiums paid under the previous program (MPP) is also available. The Dairy Margin Coverage (DMC) program allows dairy producers to purchase margin coverage from $4.00/cwt to $9.50/cwt on the first 5 million pounds of production. Producers can receive discounts on premiums by locking in coverage levels for five years and may opt for a direct cash payment of 50% of eligible repayments. The program also allows participation in both margin coverage and the Livestock Gross Margin-Dairy (LGM-D) insurance program. Additionally, the 2018 farm bill reauthorizes various dairy programs through FY2023 and establishes a milk donation program. The 2018 farm bill reauthorizes dairy programs through FY2023 and establishes a milk donation program funded at $9 million for FY2019. It also amends the formula for Class I skim milk price and directs USDA to conduct studies on feed costs and report alfalfa hay prices in top milk-producing states. USDA administers agricultural conservation programs for private landowners. The 2018 farm bill focuses on working lands, land retirement, and easement programs, reallocating funding among conservation programs. It increases short-term funding by $555 million but reduces long-term funding by $6 million. The 2018 farm bill reallocates funding among conservation programs, reducing funding by $6 million in the long term (FY2019-FY2028). The two largest working lands programs, EQIP and CSP, see reductions in total funding compared to prior law. The enacted bill combines elements from both the House and Senate proposals regarding CSP and EQIP. The enacted 2018 farm bill reauthorizes the Conservation Stewardship Program (CSP) with amendments, shifting enrollment limits from acreage to funding levels. Savings from CSP limits are redirected to other conservation programs like EQIP. Changes include new ranking criteria, contract renewal requirements, and payments for various conservation practices. A grassland conservation initiative is added to CSP, while EQIP is reauthorized and expanded to provide financial and technical assistance to producers and landowners. The enacted bill increases EQIP funding from $1.75 billion in FY2019 to $2.025 billion in FY2023, with amendments focusing on water quality, soil health, and wildlife habitat. Allocation for livestock practices decreases to 50% while wildlife practices increase to 10%. Water conservation payments now include irrigation and drainage entities. Conservation Innovation Grants expand to include community colleges and soil health trials. Land retirement programs offer federal payments for land-use restrictions. The 2018 farm bill reauthorizes and expands the Conservation Reserve Program (CRP), offering annual rental payments to landowners for land-use restrictions. CRP enrollment increases to 27 million acres by FY2023, with limits on grasslands and continuous contracts. Payments to participants are reduced, with annual rental payments capped at 85-90% of the county average. The 2018 farm bill expands the Conservation Reserve Program (CRP) by increasing enrollment to 27 million acres by FY2023. The bill also introduces new pilot programs like CLEAR 30 and reauthorizes existing subprograms. The Agricultural Conservation Easement Program (ACEP) is reauthorized and amended to provide financial and technical assistance through agricultural land easements and wetland reserve easements. The 2018 farm bill reauthorizes and amends the Agricultural Conservation Easement Program (ACEP) to focus on agricultural land easements, providing additional flexibilities to eligible entities. Changes include amendments to nonfederal cost share requirements, geographical differences consideration, terms and conditions of easements, and certification criteria. The bill also increases funding for ACEP from $250 million in FY2018 to $450 million annually for FY2019-FY2023. The 2018 farm bill reauthorizes and amends the Regional Conservation Partnership Program (RCPP) by shifting it to a standalone program with separate contracts and agreements. RCPP funding is increased to $300 million annually for FY2019-FY2023. The bill provides additional flexibilities to partners in terms of project contributions, guidance, reporting requirements, agreement renewals, and the application process. The 2018 farm bill includes amendments to conservation programs and provisions outside of farm bill legislation. It also addresses U.S. international food aid and agricultural export programs, including the Food for Peace program which receives about $1.5 billion annually. Reports on natural resources and pilot programs are required to be provided to Congress. The 2018 farm bill includes amendments to conservation programs and provisions outside of farm bill legislation. The Food for Peace (FFP) program receives about $1.5 billion annually and recent farm bills have added flexibility to purchase food in local markets or provide cash or vouchers to recipients. The U.S. Agency for International Development administers FFP, while the Foreign Agricultural Service of USDA administers other programs. The bill reauthorizes international food aid programs and includes provisions to avoid market disruption in recipient countries. The enacted law amends the Food for Peace program by eliminating the requirement to monetize at least 15% of commodities and increasing the minimum level of funds allocated for nonemergency assistance. It also authorizes up to 10% of funds to be used to purchase food in the country or region where it will be distributed. Additionally, the law extends authority for several related international programs and fellowship programs. The P.L. 115-334 law consolidates U.S. export promotion programs into one section, providing permanent mandatory funding for programs like MAP, FMDP, EMP, TASC, and establishing a Priority Trade Fund. The programs are authorized to receive $255 million in annual mandatory CCC funds for FY2019-FY2023, with specific allocations for each program. The P.L. 115-334 law consolidates U.S. export promotion programs, authorizing funding levels for EMP and TASC at $1 million less than in the 2014 farm bill. MAP and FMDP funds can now be used for programs in Cuba. The law also reauthorizes direct credits for agricultural exports to emerging markets, allocates funds to address trade barriers for biotechnology products, and requires USDA to include tribal food products in trade activities. Additionally, the Nutrition title of the farm bill amends aspects of SNAP and related programs. The enacted 2018 farm bill's Nutrition title reauthorizes SNAP and related programs for five years through FY2023. CBO estimates the impact on direct spending to be cost-neutral over a 10-year period. The bill largely maintains current SNAP eligibility and benefit calculation rules, with debate over work requirements resulting in the maintenance of existing policies. The enacted 2018 farm bill reauthorizes SNAP and related programs for five years through FY2023. The conference report maintains existing work requirements and time limits for nondisabled adults receiving SNAP, with some amendments. It reduces exemptions from the time limit to 12% and expands SNAP E&T activities. The new law simplifies benefit calculations for homeless households and requires updates on certain aspects of benefit calculation. The House-passed bill proposed various changes to SNAP eligibility, including limits on categorical eligibility, amendments to asset limits, expanded work requirements, and increased earned income deduction. The enacted 2018 farm bill includes measures to reduce errors and fraud in SNAP, such as establishing a National Accuracy Clearinghouse and increasing USDA oversight of state systems. The enacted 2018 farm bill increases USDA's oversight of state systems and the quality control system for benefit amounts. It also repeals funding for state performance awards and makes policy changes for SNAP's EBT system and benefit redemption, including limits on fees, changes in authorization requirements for farmers' market operators, and nationwide implementation of online acceptance of SNAP benefits. Additionally, the bill authorizes a pilot project for SNAP recipients to use mobile technology to redeem benefits. The 2018 farm bill expands SNAP incentive programs, increasing funding for the Gus Schumacher FINI grant program. It establishes grants for produce prescription projects to serve individuals eligible for SNAP or Medicaid with diet-related health conditions. The new law increases FINI funding by $417 million over 10 years. Additionally, the Nutrition title includes policies for retailer incentive programs and authorizes pilot projects with discretionary funding. The new law reauthorizes and makes policy changes to nutrition assistance programs, including the Food Distribution Program on Indian Reservations and the Commodity Supplemental Food Program. It also increases funding for The Emergency Food Assistance Program. The 2018 farm bill reauthorizes nutrition assistance programs and policies, including the Senior Farmers' Market Nutrition Program and funding for school meals programs. It also increases funding for The Emergency Food Assistance Program by $206 million over 10 years, including $4 million annually for projects facilitating the donation of raw commodities to emergency feeding organizations. Additionally, the bill reduces funding for the Community Food Projects grant program and authorizes new actions to enforce Buy American requirements for school meals. The 2018 farm bill reauthorizes and makes changes to USDA farm loan programs, including adding specific criteria for beginning farmers to qualify for loans and raising the maximum loan size to $1.75 million. It also authorizes new programs for Public-Private Partnerships and Micro-Grants for Food Security. The 2018 farm bill increases the loan size for guaranteed loans to $1.75 million per borrower, adjusts for inflation thereafter, and raises the farm ownership loan limit to $600,000 and the farm operating loan limit to $400,000 for direct loans. It also increases the percentage of loans guaranteed for beginning and socially disadvantaged farmers to 95%. The State Agricultural Loan Mediation Program is reauthorized through FY2023, and the Farm Credit System eliminates obsolete references and clarifies information sharing with the Farm Credit Administration. The 2018 farm bill expands the Farm Credit Administration's jurisdiction to hold "institution-affiliated parties" accountable and repeals a compensation limit for FCS bank boards of directors. It also increases the acreage exception for FarmerMac loans to 2,000 acres and provides greater guidance for the Farm Credit System Insurance Corporation's powers and duties. The 2018 farm bill expands the Farm Credit Administration's jurisdiction and repeals a compensation limit for FCS bank boards of directors. It also increases the acreage exception for FarmerMac loans and provides guidance for the Farm Credit System Insurance Corporation's powers and duties. Additionally, the bill addresses the rights and duties of parties affected by an FCS institution being placed into conservatorship or receivership, modeled after provisions for depository institutions insured by the FDIC. The bill also directs studies on agricultural credit, including reports on FSA farm loan programs, risks and capitalization of FCS and FarmerMac loans, credit availability for socially disadvantaged farmers, and credit needs of Indian tribes. The 2018 farm bill (P.L. 115-334) addresses rural development policies including broadband deployment, opioid abuse, rural health, and business and infrastructure development. It authorizes assistance prioritization for USDA Rural Development programs during public health emergencies and directs assistance prioritization for substance use disorder combatting programs. Additionally, it allocates 20% of Distance Learning and Telemedicine Program funds for telemedicine projects focusing on substance use disorder treatment services. Priority is given to entities providing substance use prevention, treatment, and recovery in the Community Facilities Program and Rural Health and Safety Education Program. The new law (P.L. 115-334) expands the Rural Broadband Access Loan and Loan Guarantee Program to include grants for broadband deployment projects, increasing authorized appropriations to $350 million annually. It also raises the minimum acceptable levels of broadband service in rural areas to 25 Mbps download and 3 Mbps upload. Additionally, the law allows loans or loan guarantees to refinance rural hospitals' debt and reauthorizes the Rural Gigabit Network Pilot. The new law (P.L. 115-334) expands broadband access programs, increases funding to $350 million annually, sets minimum service levels at 25 Mbps download and 3 Mbps upload, reauthorizes the Rural Gigabit Network Pilot, establishes the Broadband Innovative Advancement program, codifies the Community Connect Grant Program, creates a Rural Broadband Integration Working Group, directs the Northern Border Regional Commission to establish a State Capacity Building Grant Program, and forms a Council on Rural Community Innovation and Economic Development. The new law (P.L. 115-334) expands broadband access programs, increases funding to $350 million annually, sets minimum service levels at 25 Mbps download and 3 Mbps upload, reauthorizes the Rural Gigabit Network Pilot, establishes the Broadband Innovative Advancement program, and forms a Council on Rural Community Innovation and Economic Development. It also amends various programs related to rural energy savings, water assistance, and the definition of rural in the ConAct. The 2018 farm bill expands broadband access programs, establishes a technical assistance program, modifies the Cushion of Credit Payments Program, and authorizes funding for the Rural Economic Development Loan and Grant Program. The Agriculture Improvement Act of 2018 reauthorizes funding for agricultural research and education programs through FY2023 with mandatory or discretionary funding. It also repeals unfunded programs and designates new research areas as high priorities. The Agriculture Improvement Act of 2018 reauthorizes funding for agricultural research and education programs through FY2023. Key priorities include macadamia tree health, national turfgrass research, fertilizer management, cattle fever ticks, and laying hen and turkey research. The law also increases funding for the Organic Agriculture Research and Extension Initiative to $30 million annually and reauthorizes the Specialty Crop Research Initiative with carve-out funding for the Emergency Citrus Disease Research Program. Additionally, new programs are introduced for 1890 land-grant institutions, 1994 tribal colleges of agriculture, urban and indoor agricultural production, and industrial hemp research and development. The Agriculture Improvement Act of 2018 reauthorizes funding for agricultural research and education programs through FY2023. It authorizes new funding for industrial hemp research and development, supports advanced agricultural research, and creates a scholarship program for students attending 1890 land-grant universities. Additionally, it establishes Centers of Excellence for research and extension activities in defined areas such as nutrition, wellness, farming systems, and rural prosperity. The Agriculture Improvement Act of 2018 authorizes funding for agricultural research and education programs through FY2023. It includes provisions for industrial hemp research, scholarships for students at 1890 land-grant universities, and Centers of Excellence for research in various areas. Additionally, it supports tribal colleges and expands opportunities for hemp production under the Critical Agricultural Materials Act. The Agriculture Improvement Act of 2018 authorizes funding for agricultural research and education programs through FY2023, including provisions for industrial hemp research and scholarships for students at 1890 land-grant universities. It also supports tribal colleges and expands opportunities for hemp production under the Critical Agricultural Materials Act by amending and expanding provisions in the 2014 farm bill. The Secretary is directed to conduct a study of hemp production pilot programs to determine economic viability, and a new "Hemp Production" subtitle under the Agricultural Marketing Act of 1946 expands eligibility to other producers and groups, including tribes and territories. States or Indian tribes wanting regulatory authority over hemp production must implement specific plans to monitor and regulate production. Additionally, new programs supporting advanced agricultural research and development, including urban, indoor, and emerging agricultural production systems, are established. AGARDA, a component of the Office of the Chief Scientist, focuses on advanced research and development in food and agriculture through a pilot program targeting long-term and high-risk research. It accelerates innovative agricultural research, prototype testing, and licensing under the Plant Protection Act and the Animal Health Protection Act. The Secretary will develop a strategic plan for AGARDA in consultation with federal research agencies and other stakeholders to expedite contract and grant awards and appointments of qualified scientists. The enacted bill authorizes a fund with an appropriation of $50 million annually for FY2019-FY2023 to expedite contract and grant awards for scientists and research program managers. It also includes a new Urban, Indoor, and Emerging Agricultural Production Initiative for competitive grants to develop urban and indoor agricultural systems, new markets, and technologies for increased food production. The 2018 farm bill includes provisions for increased food production through new crop varieties and agricultural products, with funding allocated for urban and indoor agriculture studies. The forestry title addresses forestry research and financial assistance programs for nonfederal forest landowners. The 2018 farm bill reauthorizes forestry programs such as the Healthy Forests Reserve Program and Rural Revitalization Technology through FY2023. It also provides funding for implementing statewide forest resource assessments. The 2018 farm bill reauthorizes forestry programs and provides funding for statewide forest resource assessments. It also modifies existing assistance programs and addresses issues related to biomass accumulation and wildfire risk. The Timber Innovation Act in the 2018 farm bill establishes assistance programs for wood innovation and hazardous fuel reduction projects, with annual appropriations of up to $20 million. It also reduces funding for the Forest Service's hazardous fuels management program and repeals other biomass-related programs. The 2018 farm bill includes provisions for a wood fiber recycling research program and changes in how the Forest Service and BLM comply with environmental requirements for sage grouse and mule deer habitat management. It establishes a categorical exclusion for certain activities, with projects up to 4,500 acres exempt from environmental assessment. The bill also includes provisions related to the Forest Service's authority to designate insect and disease treatment areas on NFS lands. The enacted farm bill expands priority project categories on NFS lands, authorizes larger projects, addresses federal and tribal forest management issues, reauthorizes the Collaborative Forest Landscape Restoration Program, and authorizes conveyance of certain forest management activities. The enacted farm bill expands priority project categories on NFS lands, authorizes conveyance of NFS land through lease, sale, or exchange, reauthorizes the Facility Realignment and Enhancement program, and establishes two watershed protection programs on NFS lands. Additionally, the bill supports agriculture-based renewable energy through various programs and initiatives. The 2018 farm bill establishes a new grant program focused on carbon sequestration and biogas education, amends definitions for Biomass Crop Assistance Program, and includes algae as eligible material. It also modifies definitions for biobased products, biorefinery, and renewable energy systems. Mandatory funding is less than previous farm bills, with $375 million authorized for FY2019-FY2023. The 2018 farm bill reauthorizes various programs with funding allocated over five years, including the Markets Program, Biorefinery Assistance Program, Bioenergy Program, Rural Energy for America Program, and Feedstock Flexibility Program. Discretionary appropriations are authorized for specialty crop, certified organic agriculture, and local foods sectors. Mandatory funding is not provided for certain programs like the Biodiesel Fuel Education Program and Biomass Crop Assistance Program. The 2018 farm bill reauthorizes programs for specialty crop, certified organic agriculture, and local foods sectors with funding over five years. Provisions cover various initiatives such as block grants, support for farmers markets, education on food safety and biotechnology, and organic certification. Changes are made to farmers markets and local foods promotion programs, expanding market development and promotion initiatives. The 2018 farm bill reauthorizes programs for specialty crop, certified organic agriculture, and local foods sectors with funding over five years. It includes changes to farmers markets and local foods promotion programs, creating a new "Local Agriculture Market Program" with mandatory funding of $50 million for FY2019 and beyond. Additionally, the law addresses concerns about organic import integrity by strengthening tracking, data collection, and investigation of organic product imports. The 2018 farm bill reauthorizes programs for specialty crop, certified organic agriculture, and local foods sectors with increased funding over five years. It strengthens tracking, data collection, and investigation of organic product imports, amends eligibility and consultation requirements of the National Organic Standards Board, and expands funding for the National Organic Certification Cost Share Program. Additionally, it includes provisions to facilitate the commercial cultivation, processing, and marketing of industrial hemp in the United States. The 2018 farm bill includes provisions to facilitate the commercial cultivation, processing, and marketing of industrial hemp in the United States. It amends the Controlled Substances Act to exclude hemp from the definition of marijuana, establishes a regulatory framework for hemp production under USDA oversight, and expands eligibility to produce hemp to a broader set of producers and groups. States or tribes seeking regulatory authority over hemp production must implement the new hemp program. States and tribal governments must implement a plan to regulate hemp production under USDA oversight. Those without approved plans will be subject to USDA-established regulations. Hemp production without a USDA license is unlawful. Provisions in the law allow hemp producers to participate in federal crop insurance and USDA research programs. The federal crop insurance program offers subsidized policies to farmers for yield or revenue losses. The Federal Crop Insurance Corporation (FCIC) offers policies with guarantees like index policies based on weather conditions. Policy holders pay a balance while Approved Insurance Providers deliver policies with subsidies from FCIC. The 2018 farm bill modifies the federal crop insurance program, administered by the USDA Risk Management Agency. The 2018 farm bill modifies the federal crop insurance program, decreasing outlays by $104 million over FY2019-FY2028. It includes an increase in coverage for forage and grazing, allowing separate insurance policies for crops with multiple uses. The 2018 farm bill includes sections that project outlay increases compared to prior law. One section redefines beginning farmer or rancher eligibility for federal subsidy benefits for research and development of whole-farm insurance plans. Another section authorizes FCIC to waive certain requirements for proposals related to hemp production, adding hemp to eligible crops for federal crop insurance subsidies. The 2018 farm bill adds hemp to eligible crops for federal crop insurance subsidies, including coverage for post-harvest losses. It also raises the administrative fee for catastrophic level coverage and includes sections with projected reductions in outlays related to research and development contracts, enterprise units, and consolidation of funding. The Agriculture Improvement Act of 2018 includes provisions for hemp in federal crop insurance, administrative fee increases, reductions in outlays for research and development contracts, enterprise units, and program integrity. The Miscellaneous title covers various issues across six subtitles, with enacted provisions organized by subtitle. The 2018 farm bill establishes the National Animal Disease Preparedness Response Program (NADPRP) and the National Animal Vaccine and Veterinary Countermeasures Bank (NAVVCB) to address risks to U.S. livestock from animal diseases. The NAVVCB is directed to maintain vaccine and diagnostic products for disease outbreaks, prioritizing foot-and-mouth disease. Mandatory funding of $120 million for FY2019-FY2022 and $30 million for FY2023 onwards is authorized, along with $30 million annually for NAHLN. The 2018 farm bill authorizes annual appropriations for NAHLN, NADPRP, and NAVVCB. It includes provisions for the Sheep Production and Marketing Grant Program, a study on livestock dealer trust, and coverage for llamas, alpacas, live fish, and crawfish under the Emergency Livestock Feed Assistance Act. The bill also calls for a report on USDA's guidance to small meat processors and establishes regional cattle and carcass grading centers. Additionally, the USDA Office of Homeland Security is repealed and reestablished under the Department of Agriculture Reorganization Act of 1994. The 2018 farm bill authorizes USDA to conduct Disease and Pest of Concern Response Planning, establish a National Plant Diagnostic Network, and establish a National Plant Disease Recovery System. It also amends criteria for adding biological agents or toxins to the list and expands USDA activities for beginning, socially disadvantaged, and veteran farmers. Additionally, it prioritizes youth agricultural programs, establishes a Tribal Advisory Committee, and authorizes $50 million in funding for the Farming Opportunities Training. The 2018 farm bill includes $50 million in discretionary funding for the Farming Opportunities Training and Outreach program from FY2019-FY2023. It also establishes an Office of Urban Agriculture and Innovative Production within USDA. Additionally, the bill addresses USDA reorganizational changes and requires the re-establishment of the position of Under Secretary of Agriculture for Rural Development. The new law amends USDA duties, creates a Rural Health Liaison, and requires a civil rights analysis. It includes 40 provisions covering various issues, such as protecting animals with shelter and banning slaughter of dogs and cats. The 2018 farm bill reauthorizes trust funds, establishes a Citrus Disease Research Fund, extends the National Oilheat Research Alliance, and creates a Commission on Farm Transition and Century Farms program. It also requires USDA to conduct studies on various topics. The 2018 farm bill directs USDA to restore exemptions for weighing and inspection services, clarifies export permission requirements for the green sea urchin, and amends the Controlled Substances Act. The 2018 farm bill amends the Controlled Substances Act to exclude industrial hemp from the definition of marijuana.
